awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Sites: Type I - Texas Tech University I-Corps Site for Innovation and Entrepreneurship
awd_abstract_narration:
The Texas Tech University (TTU), through a National Science Foundation I-Corps Site (Site) award, promotes the growth of innovative ideas into commercially viable products in the South Plains of Texas and Eastern New Mexico.

Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

The TTU Site promotes, encourages, mentors, and catalyzes the translation of research with commercial potential. Focus areas include healthcare, natural resources such as food, fiber, and energy, including cybersecurity, which are all major components of the local economy. The TTU Site accelerates successful licensing and business formation of productized technologies. The TTU Site grows the existing ecosystem by also offering entrepreneurial curricula to students, faculty and the community while deepening the awareness of commercialization practices through the Business Model Canvas and Lean Startup methodologies. Finally, the TTU Site strengthens innovation locally, regionally, and in collaboration with the national NSF I-Corps network to grow the quality and quantity of teams in the pursuit of commercialization, validation, and startup creation. The TTU Mentors program supplies the teams with qualified and motivated mentors to assist in a broad range of business activities, including: marketing, intellectual property law, sales, product development, accounting, finance, and human resources. The TTU Site benefits the local and state economies through the economic development gains achieved by students, faculty and the community as they start new businesses. In addition, TTU serves a large and growing Hispanic population (approx. 27% of the student body), as well as many veterans.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Texas Tech University's NSF I-Corps Site grant has had a significant impact on the university's entrepreneurial ecosystem and commercialization practices. Here are the key outcomes and achievements:

1.     Researcher Engagement:

  • 144 teams have been trained through the I-Corps Site program since 2018.
  • 29 teams from Texas Tech University participated in the national I-Corps program.
  • The program successfully recruited over 75 teams within the initial three-year grant period.

 2.     Entrepreneurial Training Programs:

Three novel academic programs were developed to enhance entrepreneurial training for students.

  • The STEM MBA Integrative I-Corps project funded by VentureWell provided 9-credit hour courses where teams of students collaborated and developed a commercialization and customer discovery plan based on faculty-developed technologies. The program aims to provide students with an understanding of the innovation and iteration process, assessing value, and developing next steps along the commercialization pathway. 
  • TTU's Engineering Design 1 (ED1) and 2 (ED2) capstone courses partnered engineering students with medical students through TTUHSC?s Sling Health program. Sling Health is a student-run biotechnology incubator providing resources, training, and mentorship to student teams. Medical and engineering students collaborate to develop solutions to ?real-world? healthcare problems while gaining valuable experience in innovation, entrepreneurship and interprofessional collaboration. This program is currently funded by the TTUHSC Office of Student Life and VentureWell. Sling Health teams further participate in the regional I-Corps program to validate their problem statements and focus on product development.
  • The Faculty C-Startup program awards grants to faculty ?ambassadors? to develop new courses or enhance existing ones using the Business Model Canvas and Lean LaunchPad methodologies. This program supports faculty across all disciplines program and has fostered a culture of innovation and entrepreneurship across TTU.

 3.     Recognition and Awards:

  • The Faculty C-Startup program received the "Most Innovative Program Award" at the International Business Innovation Association meeting in 2023.
  • Texas Tech University currently has 35 faculty ambassadors promoting innovation and entrepreneurship across disciplines.

 4.     Virtual "Partner" Training Program (VPTP):

  • A supplemental award allowed the development of the VPTP, creating a virtual video library on Business Model Canvas principles.
  • The VPTP provides valuable resources to faculty ambassadors, I-Corps teams, and other Innovation Hub program participants.

 5.     Funding and Investment:

  • I-Corps Site teams were supported in applying for NSF I-Corps Teams grant and internal award competitions like the TTU Accelerator, Prototype Fund, and Presidents' Innovative Startup Award.
  • Total additional funds invested by Texas Tech University for the 29 National teams recommended from the Site program exceeded $450,000.
  • Overall funds invested in all Texas Tech University System (TTUS) National teams surpassed $1 Million.

 The NSF I-Corps Site grant at Texas Tech University has successfully cultivated an entrepreneurial culture, provided training and resources to researchers, and facilitated the commercialization of innovative technologies. These achievements have contributed to the university's impact on the local and regional entrepreneurial ecosystem, fostering economic growth and innovation.

 


Last Modified: 06/29/2023
Modified by: Tim Dallas

Image
  • The Innovation Hub is the focal point of the innovation and commercialization programs for the TTU System. I-CORP Site training and activities are hosted here.

    TTU Innovation Hub
por.por_txt_cntn:
Texas Tech University's NSF I-Corps Site grant has had a significant impact on the university's entrepreneurial ecosystem and commercialization practices. Here are the key outcomes and achievements:

1.     Researcher Engagement:

144 teams have been trained through the      I-Corps Site program since 2018.
29 teams from Texas Tech University      participated in the national I-Corps program.
The program successfully recruited over 75      teams within the initial three-year grant period.


 2.     Entrepreneurial Training Programs:

Three novel academic programs were developed to enhance entrepreneurial training for students.

The STEM MBA Integrative I-Corps project funded by VentureWell provided 9-credit hour courses where teams of students collaborated and developed a commercialization and customer discovery plan based on faculty-developed technologies. The program aims to provide students with an understanding of the innovation and iteration process, assessing value, and developing next steps along the commercialization pathway. 
TTU's Engineering Design 1 (ED1) and 2 (ED2) capstone courses partnered engineering students with medical students through TTUHSC?s Sling Health program. Sling Health is a student-run biotechnology incubator providing resources, training, and mentorship to student teams. Medical and engineering students collaborate to develop solutions to ?real-world? healthcare problems while gaining valuable experience in innovation, entrepreneurship and interprofessional collaboration. This program is currently funded by the TTUHSC Office of Student Life and VentureWell. Sling Health teams further participate in the regional I-Corps program to validate their problem statements and focus on product development.
The Faculty C-Startup program awards grants to faculty ?ambassadors? to develop new courses or enhance existing ones using the Business Model Canvas and Lean LaunchPad methodologies. This program supports faculty across all disciplines program and has fostered a culture of innovation and entrepreneurship across TTU.


 3.     Recognition and Awards:

The Faculty C-Startup program received the      "Most Innovative Program Award" at the International Business      Innovation Association meeting in 2023.
Texas Tech University currently has 35      faculty ambassadors promoting innovation and entrepreneurship across      disciplines.


 4.     Virtual "Partner" Training Program (VPTP):

A supplemental award allowed the      development of the VPTP, creating a virtual video library on Business      Model Canvas principles.
The VPTP provides valuable resources to faculty      ambassadors, I-Corps teams, and other Innovation Hub program participants.


 5.     Funding and Investment:

I-Corps Site teams were supported in      applying for NSF I-Corps Teams grant and internal award competitions like      the TTU Accelerator, Prototype Fund, and Presidents' Innovative Startup      Award.
Total additional funds invested by Texas      Tech University for the 29 National teams recommended from the Site      program exceeded $450,000.
Overall funds invested in all Texas Tech      University System (TTUS) National teams surpassed $1 Million.


 The NSF I-Corps Site grant at Texas Tech University has successfully cultivated an entrepreneurial culture, provided training and resources to researchers, and facilitated the commercialization of innovative technologies. These achievements have contributed to the university's impact on the local and regional entrepreneurial ecosystem, fostering economic growth and innovation.
